University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100039, PR China) ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this paper, the CePMoTiOx catalysts synthesized by via solvothermal synthesis method, the advantages of phosphorus and molybdenum were obviously represented in the performance of catalyst SCR. The arrangement of each component was more reasonable and the synergistic interaction between the components was promoted. The CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts were synthesized via a solvothermal method and phosphorous or molybdenum was effectively doped into the cerium- titanium catalyst system. Although each component of the catalysts presented a high dispersion, which was clarified by crystal structure analysis, the performance of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) was dramatically individual. Three kinds of catalysts were systematically analyzed, which confirmed significant difference in microstructure and chemical characteristics. Notably, the CePMoTiOx catalyst exhibited a superior SCR reactivity, not only the NO conversion more than 80% ranging from 260 to 440 °C, but also displayed satisfactory H2O/SO2 durability and the airspeed resistance. It was verified that the trapping sites, oxygen vacancies, Brønsted acid sites and the specific surface areas were definitely promoted, pore channel was optimized, synergistic interaction among the components and reducibility were enhanced, which benefited from a suitable amount of phosphorus and molybdenum simultaneously doping into cerium-titanium catalyst. It was obvious that the advantages of phosphorus and molybdenum were combined for CePMoTiOx by a facile way. Meanwhile, it confirmed that the Mo species were apt to associate with SO2, which preserved high SCR activity during the SO2 resistance. These detailed studies could establish basic theory and provide some significant concepts for the construction of subsequent high performance catalysts. Keywords Solvothermal synthesis Selective catalytic reduction Trapping sites and oxygen vacancies Microstructure and reducibility 1 Introduction Human health and social sustainable development have been plagued by environmental pollution, especially the problem of atmospheric pollution and climate warming is particularly fraught, and the emission of nitrogen oxides is considered as one of the major atmospheric pollution [1–3]. The SCR has been applied to control and relief NOx emissions from power plants, V2O5–WO3 (MoO3)/ TiO2 commercial catalysts have been studied and applied for decades [4–8]. Nevertheless, vanadium catalysts are less and less utilized because of the innate disadvantages such as biological toxicity and narrow temperature range. The rare earth (cerium based) catalysts have been regarded as one of the most promising alternative to vanadium- based catalyst, attributing to eco-friendly, inexpensive and abundant reserves [9–12]. Ce-based catalysts have been more and more researched for the SCR due to the remarkable oxygen storage capacity [13,14]. However, there are many challenges in the practical application of Ce-based catalysts, such as poor thermal stability, weak resistance to water and sulfur, etc. Therefore, it is prospective and necessary to improve the performance of cerium catalyst by taking reasonable measures. Cerium dioxide, which was uniformly loaded or dispersed on surface and tunnel structures of titanium dioxide by the impregnation or coprecipitation method, can not only improve the dispersion but also promote the adsorption capacity of the reactants by using the surface acidity of titanium dioxide [9,15–17] and benefiting from the abundant acid sites existing on the surface of titanium dioxide. In addition, the SCR performance can be significantly improved by doping transition metal elements, such as molybdenum or tungsten, ascribe to increase defects and oxygen vacancies and improve the synergistic interaction among catalyst components. More importantly, it is reported that some inorganic elements (such as phosphorus) can improve the surface acidity of cerium catalysts and increase the activity at low temperature [18]. Some researchers report that adding phosphorus could not only increase the acidic sites on the surface of the Ce-based catalyst [18–20]. On the contrary, a series of studies reported that the addition of a few of phosphorus have a significant deactivation effect on SCR reaction for the CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst [21,22]. On the one hand, the structure was destroyed and more deactivated compounds were formed, such as CePO4. On the other, redox properties and the synergistic effect between components declined seriously [21–23]. Therefore, it is necessary to use an ideal synthesis to improve the activity of catalyst by effectively doping phosphorus. Herein, some positive and effective strategies are studied in this work, phosphorus and molybdenum were doped in ceria-titanium metal oxides via a solvothermal synthesis, and the CePMoTiOx catalyst exhibited superior performance on SCR reaction. More importantly, the CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts were prepared through the same process, while showing significant differences in activity. Moreover, these catalysts are characterized and analyzed in detail, through comprehensive study catalyst crystal structure, pore structure, redox properties of SCR activity, exploring structure-activity relationship between catalysts internal, as to provide theoretical basis for study of high-performance catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All catalysts were synthesized via a solvothermal method, which had been reported minutely in our previous works [24,25], different structure of the catalysts were prepared in accordance with the above methods, and as showed in Fig. 1 . In the present study, CePMoTiOx, 2.4 g of urea, 0.5 mL of hydrochloric acid and 1.16 g of Pluronic P123 were mixed in ethanol (20.0 mL) under stirring intensely, which was labeled A solution. 0.5 mL of hydrochloric acid and 5.32 g of tetrabutyl titanate were mingled in ethanol (20.0 mL) with violent stirring, 1.34 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 0.312 g of ammonium phosphate and 0.27 g of hexaammonium molybdate were added respectively into the ethanol solution, in brief, Ce: Mo: P: Ti = 2: 1: 1: 10 in molar proportions, which was viewed as B ingredient. Then, the A and B ingredients were mixed into a 100 mL PTFE autoclave and maintained at 80 °C for 48 h, and rose to 120 °C for 5 h. Eventually, the samples were assembled by filtration and washed by alcohol three times, dried at 100 °C for 12 h and annealed in air at 400 °C for 3 h (2 °C min−1). As a contrast, CeTiOx, CePTiOx and CeMoTiOx were prepared through the same process. In addition, the effect of different contents was also studied for the phosphorus, for instance, CeP0.05MoTiOx and CeP0.2MoTiOx. 2.2 Analytical instrumentation XRD patterns were characterized by X′ Pert PRO, PANalytical with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 55 mA). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was observed by JEOL JEM-2010. Laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS) was determined by a RM 2000 microscope (514 nm). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was measured at room temperature using a Bruker A300-9.5/ 12-type spectrometer. N2 adsorption- desorption isotherms were determined by a ASAP 2020 Micromeritics. Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was determined by a NEXUS 870 Thermo. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were investigated by ESCALAB 250Xi, ThermoFisher Scientific. The hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was measured by DAS-7000 (5 vol. % H2, 95 vol. % N2 and 40 mL min−1). The tests conditions of ammonia gas temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and H2-TPR are the same. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The SCR performance was measured in a static bed miniature evaluation device using 0.4 or 0.12 g of the catalysts, when employing 0.4 g (0.12 g), the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) value was calculated as 30, 000 h−1(100, 000 h−1). The reaction system was performed as expected ranging of 100–480 °C. Meanwhile, the feed gas mixture was consisted of 500 ppm NO, 5 vol% O2, 500 ppm NH3, 100 ppm SO2, 3 or 10 vol% H2O, N2 was used as a balance gas. The concentrations of NO and SO2 were continuously detected by a KM9106. The NO percent conversion was calculated according to the following expression [25,26]: (1) NO conversion ( % ) = NO i n l e t − NO o u t l e t NO i n l e t × 100 % A relative turnover frequency (TOF) value was employed to match the SCR velocity under a GHSV of 100, 000 h−1. Which was evaluated draw on the equation [25–28]: (2) TOF = ( P F 0 / RT ) α m c a t β C e / M C e Where P is 101 kPa, F 0 is the flow velocity of reaction (0.1 mL min−1), R is 8.314 J mol−1 K−1, α is the NO transformation (%), mcat is 0.12 g of the sample, β C e is Ce content (%) and MCe is 140.1 g mol−1. T is 393, 413, 433 and 453 K test temperature point. The reaction rate ( r ) and activation energy was assessed in accordance with the expression [2,4,5]: (3) r = F 0 m c a t × [ − ln ( 1 − α ) ] (4) r = k C 0 (5) k = A • exp − Ea RT (6) ln r = − Ea RT + B Where k (s−1) and B are considered constant, and the other parameters are the same as Eq. (2). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The CeTiOx, CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts were used in the NH3-SCR ranging from 100 to 480 °C, as exhibited in Fig. 2 (a). The NO conversion of the CeTiOx catalyst was 90% ranging of 260–380 °C under a GHSV of 30, 000 h−1, while the CePTiOx catalyst presented much lower conversion than that of the CeTiOx catalyst, which illustrated that phosphorus might play a toxic role in cerium- titanium NH3-SCR catalyst [17–19]. Especially, the activity was significantly decreased below 360 °C, suggesting that adsorption property of reactants might be reduced. The CeMoTiOx catalyst showed exceed 80% of NOx conversion ranging of 240–420 °C under the same GHSV, which elucidated that molybdenum species modifying CeMoTiOx catalyst exhibited superior low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. Not only could the acid sites be enhanced, but also the synergistic interaction between metal oxides was strengthened [13,28,29]. Distinctly, the CePMoTiOx catalyst presented an ascendant reactivity ranging from 200 to 400 °C, comparing with the others. It illuminated that the phosphorous and molybdenum were introduced simultaneously into the cerium- titanium catalyst system in a reasonable method, which could greatly improve the SCR reaction activity. On one hand, they could enhance the acidity of the catalyst, on the other, intrinsic defects and oxygen vacancies are increased directionally. It showed that the advantages of inorganic and transition metal elements were utilized reasonably and effectively, which has seldom been reported in the field of NH3-SCR to the best of our knowledge. In addition, the catalysts with different phosphorous contents were tested, as showed in Fig. 2(b). The catalyst CePMoTiOx exhibited better NH3-SCR activity in the temperature range of operation (200–440 °C). The appropriate phosphorous was doped into CeO2-MoO3-TiO2 catalyst system, which was advantageous to low-temperature NH3-SCR and the performance of catalysts was followed the order: CePMoTiOx＞CeP0.05MoTiO x ＞CeP0.2MoTiOx. This result illuminated that a suitable amount of phosphorus and molybdenum doped into cerium titanium catalyst, which could effectively improve the catalytic activity [30]. 3.2 H2O and SO2 resistant properties As is well-known, H2O resistance is essential to the application of catalysts. The water resistance of all the catalysts was measured with 3% vol. H2O as a function of time at 260 °C (Fig. 2c). Obviously, the CePMoTiOx catalyst preformed higher reactivity than that of others. Interestingly, The NO conversion over the CeMoTiOx catalyst declined from 98% to 90%, while that of the CePTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts had little effect during the whole H2O tolerance test. Analogously, some certain of SO2 existed exhaust gas and owned a serious inactivation on the NH3-SCR (Fig. 2d). NO conversion of the CeTiOx catalyst decreased from 95% to 70% as soon as SO2 entering mixed gases, and that of the CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts remained above 80%, suggested that the sulfur resistance of the catalysts could be improved via proper doping of molybdenum. 3.3 Activity, H2O and SO2 resistant properties at high GHSV Remarkably, in order to further investigate catalyst performance, all of the catalysts was evaluated under a high GHSV of 100 000 h−1 (Fig. 3a). The NO conversion more than 80% of the CePMoTiOx catalyst ranging from 260 to 440 °C and the performance was superior to other catalysts. It was obvious that the CePMoTiOx catalyst had a satisfactory resistance of the airspeed, which benefits from the addition of phosphorus and molybdenum into the catalyst system to improve the oxidation-reduction ability. Moreover, all of the catalysts were investigated at 260 °C (Fig. 1S†) and 300 °C (Fig. 3b) under the same GHSV with 3% vol. H2O. The NO conversion of all the CeTiOx and CeMoTiOx catalysts was significantly declined when 3 vol. % H2O vapour was turning into the reaction system at 260 °C, while that of the CePTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts had a slight decreased and the activity recovered after removing the water, which implicated that water and reactants were competing adsorption on the surface of catalysts during the tolerance of H2O test. The results were also demonstrated by 3 vol. % water resistance tests at 300 °C. Moreover, many industrial flue gases contained large amounts of water, such as ceramic furnaces. The catalysts were evaluated in more rigorous environments (100 000 h−1 GHSV, 10 vol. % H2O, Fig. 3c). The NO conversion of the CePTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts was better than that of others, which meant that the surface of the catalysts might be modified and owned water-resistant properties by doped phosphorus. The CeTiOx, CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts were examined at 260 °C (Fig. 2S†) and 300 °C (Fig. 3d) under a GHSV of 100, 000 h−1 with 100 ppm concentration of SO2. The NO conversion of the CeTiOx and CePTiOx catalyst was linear dropping from 80% to almost no any activity at 260 °C as soon as adding into 100 ppm SO2, while the activity of CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx also decreased sharply and did not distinctly recover after the SO2 gas was cutting off. However, when the temperature increased to 300 °C, The NO conversion of the CePMoTiOx catalyst was declined from 92% to 80% under the same conditions as well as recovered 82% after turning off SO2, and that of the others exhibited identical phenomena. These results illustrated that the reactants combined with SO2 and generated undecomposed compounds and covered the active sites, such as ABS (ammonium bisulfate sulfate), so that the SCR performance of the catalyst decreased obviously, which would be also confirmed by subsequent works.. Generally, there was no doubt that the NH3-SCR performance of the CePMoTiOx catalyst was improved when the phosphorous and molybdenum were doping simultaneously into the cerium- titanium catalysis system by a solvothermal method, which might be profiting from the optimization of catalyst oxidation-reduction property, increasing trapping sites, oxygen vacancies and surface chemical groups, promoting synergistic interaction between metal oxides. 3.4 Structure of the catalyst The XRD peaks of the CeTiOx, CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts are exhibited in Fig.4 (a). The CeTiOx catalyst was consisted of typical anatase and fluorite of CeO2 [9,24,25]. Astonishingly, the CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts did not display any characteristic peaks, indicating that the crystallinity of any species was weak by doping a few of phosphorus or molybdenum. Moreover, the dispersion of CePMoTiOx catalyst was superior to that of other catalysts by HRTEM (Fig. S3- 5†), which could be promoted synergistic effect of different components [15,25,28,29]. In order to distinguish some subtle differences of catalyst structure, all of the catalysts were detected by the Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 4b). Compared with CeTiOx catalyst, except for a weak peak of the CeMoTiOx catalyst located at around 462 cm−1 were identified the features of F2g (CeO2), the representative peaks of TiO2, MoO3 and CeO2 had almost not been detected. While, the signally bands of the three catalysts around 255 and 596 cm−1 were attribute to oxygen vacancies, which could accelerate the conversion frequency between chemical adsorption oxygen (Oα) and lattice oxygen (Oβ) in the transformation process of Ce3+ and Ce4+ [31–33]. The characteristic peak of the CePTiOx catalyst centered at 950 cm−1 was defined as Q0, which was attributable to the existence of non-bridging oxygen (PO) [34]. It elucidated that the defects and oxygen vacancies in the CePTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalyst were caused by the doping of phosphorus. For the sake of obtaining more accurate information about defects and oxygen vacancies, the catalysts were characterized the EPR (Fig. 5 ). The CePTiOx catalyst showed the strongest signal peaks, indicating that the unpaired electron occured in the the homogeneous phase and the titanium and phosphorus existed in high energy state. A broad resonance linewidth at g = 2.10 was identified as surface superoxide species (Ce-O2 −) [35,36]. The signal centered at g = 1.978 had been attributed to interface Ti3+, illustrating that there existed distinct classes of anatase surface trapping sites for the CePTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts [37,38]. The relatively higher signal (g = 1.96) of the CeTiOx catalyst was ascribed to Ce3+ presenting in the CeO2 bulk, which corresponded with the result of XRD [35,39]. The obviously strongest signal peak (g = 1.93) was belonged to Ce3+ emerging on the CeO2 surface [35,39]. It is obviously plentiful trapping sites and oxygen vacancies existed in the CePTiOx catalyst, while the CePMoTiOx catalyst also possessed more crystal defects and oxygen vacancies than that of the CeTiOx and CeMoTiOx catalyst (Fig. S5–9†), which was consisted with the conclusion of Raman, indicating that internal microcosmic structure of the catalyst were totally different attributing to the dopant of phosphorus or molybdenum into the CeTiOx catalyst. More oxygen vacancies might promote NO oxidation, which was tested (Fig. S10†). The rule was consistent with the above conclusion: CePTiOx＞ CePMoTiOx＞ CeMoTiOx≈ CeTiOx. In addition, the different functional groups on the surface of the catalysts were also analyzed by FTIR (Fig. 6 ). The IR bands around at 2960 and 1380 cm−1 were identified as trace of P123 templates', which illuminated that the template agents had been substantially removed from all catalysts [40]. The peaks at 1625 cm−1 corresponded to the asymmetrical change angle vibration of NH4 + species and the wave number at 1280 cm−1 were defined as nitrate species, suggesting that a handful of nitrates had not been decomposed [41–43]. The absorption peaks ranging from 3310 cm−1 to 3460 cm−1 were ascribed to the HO stretching vibration. Interestingly, In spite of the typical characteristic peaks above, the band at 1150 cm−1 were defined as stretching vibration of PH and a broad peak at around 1040 cm−1 were verified to Ti-O-P framework vibrations [44]. It indicated that a little of phosphorus was effectively doped into the titanium dioxide structure of the CePMoTiOx catalyst, under the same synthetic method, more phosphorus combined with titanium dioxide and formed more complex compounds for the CePTiOx catalyst. Therefore, the catalyst exhibited distinct difference of catalytic activity in NH3-SCR reaction, which could be explained rationally. Ammonia was firstly combined with PH or PO on the surface of the CePTiOx catalyst and uncomfortable to adsorb or activate by titanium dioxide, thereby, the “fast SCR” was obstructed at low temperature ranges, by contrast, the CePMoTiOx catalyst possessed a superior performance under a high GHSV of 100 000 h−1, profiting from a suitable amount of PO groups promoting the adsorption of ammonia. Besides, the CePTiOx catalyst showed a better activity that that of others during the whole H2O tolerance test under a higher GHSV, because the combination of PH and PO with H2O on the surface, so as to avoid competing with ammonia. Except for the defects and oxygen vacancies increased, the channel structure of the catalysts was obviously optimized after doped phosphorus and molybdenum. The porosity of the catalysts was measured by the nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms (Fig. 7 a) and the results were listed in Table 1 . The CeTiOx and CePTiOx catalysts represented a H1 isotherm of type IV, which is the cause of the accumulation of flaky particles. The CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts exhibited a H3 isotherm of type IV and a clear closed loop was constituted in the relative pressure ranging from 0.4 to 0.5, which was a typical homogeneous particle accumulation. The channel size of the CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalyst were more concentrated, which was also obtained the same conclusion from the pore diameter distribution curves (Fig. 7b). The pore channel of the CePMoTiOx catalyst was more concentrated ranging from 2 to 5 nm than that of others, implying that uniform pore channels were facilitate to SCR [32,45,46]. On the side, the specific surface area of the catalysts was increased in the regulation: CeTiOx (87.79 m2 g−1) ＜CePTiOx (139.91 m2 g−1)＜CeMoTiOx (181.28 m2 g−1) ＜CePMoTiOx (185.17 m2 g−1). Finally, the CePMoTiOx catalyst possessed higher pore volumes (0.130 cm3 g−1), implying that the pore structure of the catalyst might be improved via the appropriate mixture of phosphorus and molybdenum. 3.5 Catalysts reducibility The reducibility of the catalysts has the key effect to the NH3-SCR, which was verified by H2- TPR. All the reductive peaks were integrated via mapping for the optimum unity, as depicted in Fig. 8 (a) and the results were disposed in Table 2 . For the CePMoTiOx catalyst, the peak ranging from 350 to 450 °C was related to Oα of cerium dioxide or type Ce4+-O-Ce4+ [47–49], while that of CeMoTiOx moved about 50 °C to the high temperature region and that of CePTiOx had not been detected. It indicated that chemical adsorption oxygen of the CePMoTiOx catalyst exhibited higher activity than that of others, which was favorable to“fast-SCR” reaction. The peak of the CeMoTiOx catalyst ranging of 450–580 °C was belonged to the reductive unformed Mo species [50], that of the CePMoTiOx catalyst was not almost surveyed, suggesting that surface Mo species have better dispersion or combination with others species. The peak around 530 °C was assigned to non-stoichiometric ceria of type Ce3+-O-Ce4+ [51,52], and the temperature conformed to the following rules: CeMoTiOx (584.2 °C) ＞CePTiOx(535.1 °C) ＞CePMoTiOx (523.8 °C). Finally, the peak at 630 °C was ascribe to lattice oxygen or stoichiometric ceria of type Ce3+-O-Ce4+, that of the CePMoTiOx catalyst located at the lower temperature, which implicated that the reducibility of the catalyst has greatly been enhanced and attributed to the interoperable effect among the components via the doping of phosphorus and molybdenum. Except as the macroscopically reduction of the catalysts by H2-TPR, the more detailed information of each element was researched via XPS. The every element peak of the CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts was resolved by exploring for the optimum combination (Fig. 8b–f), and the surface atomic concentration was summarized in Table 3 . The labeled v′ and u′ of the Ce 3d peaks are defined as the 3d104f1 initial electronic state attributing to Ce3+ species. Generally speaking, when the Ce3+/ (Ce4+ + Ce3+) ratio would be higher, the transformation between Ce4+ and Ce3+ could be more frequently and the Oα was more often produced. Nevertheless, for the CePMoTiOx catalyst, Ce3+/ (Ce4++ Ce3+) ratios arranged in the middle of the three samples, while Oα/ (Oα + Oβ) ratio was the highest of all (Fig. 8c). It indicated that more the active surface oxygen was generated by defects and oxygen vacancies, ascribing to the dopant of proper phosphorus and molybdenum. It should be pointed out that the oxygen binding energy barrier has a great difference in the three catalysts (Fig. 8c). There were four species that combined with oxygen to produce different binding energies. The peak located at the highest energy state (533.0 eV) belonging to non-bridging oxygen (PO), the peak centered at 531.5 eV was defined as bridging oxygen (POP) [53,54]. For the CePTiOx catalyst, the peak of around 532.4 eV was consisted of PO and PO and the peak at 530.7 eV were relatively higher than lattice oxygen (Oβ, 530.2 eV), attributing to phosphorus forming a stable bond on the surface of titanium. In addition, the transformation of these structures could also be perceived by analyzing the XPS spectra of P 2p (Fig. 8d) and Ti 2p (Fig. 8f). The P 2p binding energy at lower energy than that of P2O5 (135.2 eV) and the bond strength located at higher energies state than that of TiO2. It was obvious that the phosphorus doping into TiO2 structure to form a stable chemical bond. Hence, it was difficult that titanium dioxide formed to crystallize, attributing to the existence of these bonds. It was possible that the titanium surface combined with plentiful phosphorus to form the P-O-Ti structure [23,55–57]. Although the acid sites of the CePTiOx catalyst were strengthened, ammonia was more likely to combine with the phosphorus species. Therefore, the CePTiOx catalyst was weaker than that of others catalyst. The peak around 531.7 eV was assigned to Oα. Regard to the CeMoTiOx catalyst, the binding energies of Oα had not been affected, suggesting that Mo species were well dispersed within metal oxides by solvothermal synthesis, and prevented the formation of bulk TiO2 or CeO2, which could be beneficial to synergy among the metal oxides, according with W. Shan’s report [50,58,59]. Observably, the Oα binging energies of the CePMoTiOx catalyst was much lower than that of the CePTiOx catalyst and it had higher Oα/ (Oα + Oβ) ratio than that of others, which implicated that the ability of oxidation and reduction was notably enhanced due to the uniformly doping of molybdenum and phosphorus. It demonstrated that the CePMoTiOx catalyst had higher SCR activity attribute to higher the active surface oxygen content, which was facilitated to the oxidation of NO oxidation and promoted the “fast SCR’’ reaction. Astoundingly, the XPS spectra of Mo 3d had been not examined any signal value (Fig. 8e). It might be low in content, but more likely that the molybdenum species were introduced into interior structure of the CePMoTiOx catalyst via solvent thermal synthesis, which could be confirmed by succeeding studies. Different structures of cerium titanium catalysts were synthesized through the same way. Only via adjusting the different doping elements, three different structures and chemical states had been established. There is a significative relationship between catalyst crystal and pore structure, chemical and catalytic performance. 3.6 Surface acidities (NH3-TPD) In addition to improving the oxidation-reduction performance of the catalyst, enhancing the surface acidity is considered to one of available approach, which can promote the adsorption of ammonia [60]. All the NH3- TPD curves had been matched (Fig. 9 ) and the data had been listed in Table 4 . The Brønsted or weak acid sites of the CePTiOx catalyst was obviously strengthened, which was consistent with Z. Wu’s report [19,20]. However, compared with the CeMoTiOx catalyst, it has relatively few strong or Lewis acid sites. The CePMoTiOx catalyst combined the advantages of the CePTiOx and CeMoTiOx catalysts, not only had more Brønsted acid sites, but also had more Lewis acid sites. It illustrated that the catalyst could efficiently absorb NH3 at a wide temperature range, which was favorable to SCR reaction. 3.7 The relative TOF and activation energy calculation results Except as detailed comparing the catalytic velocity of the three samples under a high GHSV (100, 000 h−1) at low temperature, The TOF value was evaluated [32,41], and as a operation of temperature were displayed in Fig. 10 (a). In the range of 120–180 °C, the CeMoTiOx catalyst had weak NH3-SCR performance under a high GHSV, as well as its TOF value was relatively low. On the contrary, the CePMoTiOx catalyst exhibited better NH3-SCR activity in the same temperature range and the TOF value was also higher, indicating that the doping of phosphorus was more likely to combine with the reactants under a high GHSV. For the CePTiOx catalyst, the TOF value increased rapidly in the process of temperature rising, elucidating that the suitable doping of phosphorus could promote the airspeed performance. The value of activation energy was evaluated to the Eqs. (3–6) and the data fitted in Fig. 10(b). The catalyst possessed a lower activation energy (26.70 ± 1.87 kJ mol−1) than that of others catalyst. In addition, the relationship between the Oα/Ototal and kinetic parameters presented linear (Table S1 and Fig. S11†), it illustrated that the activity of SCR was improved due to the doping of phosphorus and molybdenum into cerium- titanium catalyst, which could be increased defects, oxygen vacancies and synergistic interaction among components. 3.8 Surface component and chemical states after enduring SO2 test In order to explore more about the catalytic relationship between structure and performance, the CePMoTiOx catalyst after resistance SO2 test at 260 °C and 300 °C was additionally detected by XPS and the relevant results were represented in Fig. 11 and Table 5 . It was noteworthy that the surface atomic concentration of Mo and S were accelerated rapidly, as well as that of Ti was increased, implying SO2 might be preferential combined with Mo and Ti species to depress the activity of the catalyst during the resistance SO2 test. Meanwhile, that of P was reduced by nearly half and that of O was decreased. Although the change of Ce content was not significant, the proportion of Ce3+/ (Ce4+ + Ce3+) had been markedly changed and followed the order: fresh ＜300 °C ＜260 °C (Fig. 11a). It illuminated that the transformation between Ce4+ and Ce3+ during NH3-SCR reaction, according to the equation: 4Ce4+ + O2−↔ 4Ce4+ + 2 e− + 0.5O2 ↔ 2Ce4+ + 2Ce3+ + 0.5O2. The NO conversion was dramatically declined during SO2 test at 260 °C because the conversion process in Ce3+→ Ce4+ was hindered in the process, which was confirmed by our previous research [9,25]. Identically, after the resistance SO2 test, the binding energies of O had been also influenced and Oα/ (Oα + Oβ) performed an opposite regular : 260 °C＜ 300 °C＜ fresh, which illustrated reduction of Ce4+ was benificial to operating and the progress of oxidation of Ce3+ was inhibited. Furthermore, the percentage of Oα/ (Oα + Oβ) was obviously decreased, which suggested that the microstructure of the CePMoTiOx catalyst had been changed after the resistance SO2 test at 260 °C. It was confirmed that partial the defects and oxygen vacancies had been destroyed as well as the synergistic effect of the components had been weakened. The P 2p and Ti 2p binding located at lower energies than that of fresh, remarkably, the content of molybdenum on catalyst was significantly accelerated. It indicated that the Mo species were preferentially combined with SO2 on surface of the CePMoTiOx catalyst and the structure had been irreversible damaged, which was similar to the anti-arsenic properties of Mo in commercial catalysts [61,62]. The passivated sulfur species were also analyzed in detail via XPS. The surface S atomic content at 260 °C was much higher than that at 300 °C, suggested that the CePMoTiOx catalyst was toxic attributing to deposition of the abundant sulfur compounds. The obvious peaks located at higher binding energy (169.98 eV and 168.72 eV) were assigned to the S 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 transitions of SO4 2−, which was higher that ABS- TiO2 [63,64], deduced that the SO4 2− was not only associated with titanium dioxide, but also combined with others, such as Mo and Ce species. The weak peak at 166.69 eV was related to SO3 2− species [65], illustrating that a few of SO2 was adsorbed by TiO2. The sulfate species were more closely united with Mo species [66] to protect the active site during the resistance SO2 test at 300 °C. Binding energies of S4+ centered at 166.13 eV was lower than that at 260 °C, demonstrating that SO2 were priori associated with Mo species and possess a higher electron could density [63,64,66]. Therefore, the process of sulfur dioxide combined and decomposed on the surface molybdenum species and protected the activity sites of the CePMoTiOx catalyst above 300 °C. In order to further research the transformation about functional groups of the CePMoTiOx catalyst surface after the SO2 resistance test, the samples were examined by FTIR (Fig. 11g). Obviously, for the CePMoTiOx catalyst after enduring SO2 test at 260 °C, a broad peak at aroud 3170 cm−1 was identified as antisymmetric stretching vibration of NH4 +. Moreover, the vibration of symmetric angle (NH4 +, 1720 cm−1), asymmetric angle (NH3 +, 1620 cm−1) and antisymmetric stretching vibration of bridging nitrate species (1280 cm−1) had been stronger and wider, and a sharp and intense peak located at 1400 cm−1 was ascribed to stretching vibration peak of SO [67–71]. According to the analysis results of XPS, there are a mass of sulfates, nitrates and ammonium salts on the surface of the catalyst. It suggested that these intermediate products could not be decomposed but were combined with the titanium dioxide or other components to weaken the synergistic effect of the metal oxides at low temperature, which is the key function for the inactivation of the catalyst. 3.9 The influence mechanism of phosphorus and molybdenum element on SCR The SCR reaction activity of the cerium- titanium catalyst was designedly improved via solvothermal method with the appropriate doping of phosphorus and molybdenum simultaneously. Not only pore channel was optimized and the components were more uniformly dispersed, but also the advantages of inorganic phosphorus and transition metal molybdenum elements were obviously developed in the performance of NH3-SCR (Fig. 12 ). The arrangement of each component was more reasonable and the synergistic interaction between the components was promoted. The trapping sites and oxygen vacancies were definitely improved, as well as the adsorption of the reactants was enhanced with phosphorus groups (PH and PO) by the suitable introduction of phosphorus, which was favorable to NO conversion in the presence of water vapor and a high GHSV. The molybdenum species were effectively dispersed in the whole phase structure, which could migrate to the surface of the catalyst and protect the active centers when SO2 was contacting with the CePMoTiOx catalyst. It was seldom reported that comprehensive utilization of transition metal element and inorganic element improved the SCR performance of catalysts, which could afford professionally the speculation for design and preparation of excellent catalyst. 4 Conclusions The CeTiOx, CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts with individual microstructure and chemical properties were synthesized by solvothermal method, and their SCR performance was significantly different. For the CePTiOx catalyst, a plenty of phosphorus was doped efficiently into the structure of anatase titanium dioxide, decreased the crystallinity of components and formed a stable chemical bond, such PH and P-O-Ti. Although there are abundant Brønsted acid sites, trapping sites and oxygen vacancies, ammonia was liable to combine with the phosphorus species, difficult to contact with active centers at low temperature range, and the “fast SCR” reaction was hindered. Therefore, the low- temperature SCR activity of the CePTiOx catalyst was weaker than that of other catalysts, while the catalyst showed better resistance to water because the functional groups on its surface were more likely to combine the PH or PO with H2O rather than NH3. The CeMoTiOx catalyst exhibited preferable SCR performance, because the metal oxides kept a highly dispersed state. It can promote synergy between the components and enhance reducibility for NH3-SCR, while the airspeed resistance was expected to improve. Finally, the CePMoTiOx catalyst not only presented better 90% conversion of NO ranging from 240 °C to 420 °C, but also obtained satisfactory H2O/SO2 durability and the airspeed resistance, attributed to the propre doping of phosphorus and molybdenum into the mesoporous ceria-titanium catalyst. It is confirmed that phosphorus species highly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst, while a little of phosphorus combined with titanium dioxide and generated sufficient Brønsted acid sites, which was facilitate to the adsorption process of ammonia species. It was further worth that the molybdenum species were effectively dispersed in the whole phase structure, which not only increased the Lewis acid sites, but also promoted defects and oxygen vacancies. The H2O/SO2 resistance of the CePMoTiOx catalyst was optimized because the Mo species were liable to associated with SO2 as well as water vapour was more easily combined with phosphorus groups, and migrated to the surface of the catalyst and protected the active centers. The microstructure, redox performance and SCR characteristics of the three catalysts were analyzed in detail, which could afford professionally the speculation for design and preparation of excellent catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The CePTiOx, CeMoTiOx and CePMoTiOx catalysts were synthesized via a solvothermal method and phosphorous or molybdenum was effectively doped into the cerium- titanium catalyst system. Although each component of the catalysts presented a high dispersion, which was clarified by crystal structure analysis, the performance of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) was dramatically individual. Three kinds of catalysts were systematically analyzed, which confirmed significant difference in microstructure and chemical characteristics. Notably, the CePMoTiOx catalyst exhibited a superior SCR reactivity, not only the NO conversion more than 80% ranging from 260 to 440 °C, but also displayed satisfactory H2O/SO2 durability and the airspeed resistance. It was verified that the trapping sites, oxygen vacancies, Brønsted acid sites and the specific surface areas were definitely promoted, pore channel was optimized, synergistic interaction among the components and reducibility were enhanced, which benefited from a suitable amount of phosphorus and molybdenum simultaneously doping into cerium-titanium catalyst. It was obvious that the advantages of phosphorus and molybdenum were combined for CePMoTiOx by a facile way. Meanwhile, it confirmed that the Mo species were apt to associate with SO2, which preserved high SCR activity during the SO2 resistance. These detailed studies could establish basic theory and provide some significant concepts for the construction of subsequent high performance catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: New insight into the synergistic promotion effect of phosphorus and molybdenum on the ceria-titanium catalysts for superior SCR performance
